input:
A farm and an orchard are adjoining tracts of land located in a county. In 2006, a farmer purchased the farm, a 10-acre tract, in fee simple absolute. The orchard, a 20-acre tract situated to the north of the farm, was owned by a rancher in fee simple absolute. A remote predecessor of the farmer had granted to a shepherd a way for egress and ingress across the farm under such terms and circumstances that an easement appurtenant to the orchard was created. This right-of-way was executed by deed and properly recorded. The shepherd, however, never made any actual use of the right-of-way. In 2010, the rancher conveyed the orchard to the farmer. The next year, the farmer conveyed the orchard by deed to an investor for a consideration of $250,000, receipt of which was acknowledged. Neither the rancher farmer deed nor the farmer  investor deed contained any reference to the easement for right-of-way. The investor has now claimed that she has a right-of-way across the farm. The farmer, on the other hand, has informed the investor that no such easement exists. Assume that both the farm and the orchard abut a public highway and that ingress and egress are afforded the investor by that highway. In an appropriate action by the investor to determine her right to use the right-of-way across the farm, she should

A) win, because the farmer had constructive notice of the easement.
B) lose, because the right-of-way was abandoned inasmuch as there never was any actual use made.
C) lose, because the easement was extinguished by merger when the farmer acquired the orchard from the rancher.
D) lose, because the easement was not in use at the time of the sale to the investor.
E) lose, because the investor has reasonable access to the public highway without using the right-of-way.
F) win, because the investor has a right to access all parts of her property.
G) lose, because the easement was not specifically mentioned in the deed between the farmer and the investor.
H) win, because the right-of-way was never officially terminated.
I) win, because the investor acquired an easement by implication.
J) win, because the original deed clearly states the existence of the right-of-way.

answers: J) win, because the original deed clearly states the existence of the right-of-way.

A farm and an orchard are adjoining tracts of land located in a county. In 2006, a farmer purchased the farm, a 10-acre tract, in fee simple absolute. The orchard, a 20-acre tract situated to the north of the farm, was owned by a rancher in fee simple absolute. A remote predecessor of the farmer had granted to a shepherd a way for egress and ingress across the farm under such terms and circumstances that an easement appurtenant to the orchard was created. This right-of-way was executed by deed and properly recorded. The shepherd, however, never made any actual use of the right-of-way. In 2010, the rancher conveyed the orchard to the farmer. The next year, the farmer conveyed the orchard by deed to an investor for a consideration of $250,000, receipt of which was acknowledged. Neither the rancher farmer deed nor the farmer  investor deed contained any reference to the easement for right-of-way. The investor has now claimed that she has a right-of-way across the farm. The farmer, on the other hand, has informed the investor that no such easement exists. Assume that both the farm and the orchard abut a public highway and that ingress and egress are afforded the investor by that highway. A) win, because the farmer had constructive notice of the easement.
B) lose, because the right-of-way was abandoned inasmuch as there never was any actual use made.
C) lose, because the easement was extinguished by merger when the farmer acquired the orchard from the rancher.
D) lose, because the easement was not in use at the time of the sale to the investor.
E) lose, because the investor has reasonable access to the public highway without using the right-of-way.
F) win, because the investor has a right to access all parts of her property.
G) lose, because the easement was not specifically mentioned in the deed between the farmer and the investor.
H) win, because the right-of-way was never officially terminated.
I) win, because the investor acquired an easement by implication.
J) win, because the original deed clearly states the existence of the right-of-way.

additional_args.task_instruction: Answer the provided question by choosing one option. Include the letter corresponding to your answer in the solution.
additional_args.input_str:
A farm and an orchard are adjoining tracts of land located in a county. In 2006, a farmer purchased the farm, a 10-acre tract, in fee simple absolute. The orchard, a 20-acre tract situated to the north of the farm, was owned by a rancher in fee simple absolute. A remote predecessor of the farmer had granted to a shepherd a way for egress and ingress across the farm under such terms and circumstances that an easement appurtenant to the orchard was created. This right-of-way was executed by deed and properly recorded. The shepherd, however, never made any actual use of the right-of-way. In 2010, the rancher conveyed the orchard to the farmer. The next year, the farmer conveyed the orchard by deed to an investor for a consideration of $250,000, receipt of which was acknowledged. Neither the rancher farmer deed nor the farmer  investor deed contained any reference to the easement for right-of-way. The investor has now claimed that she has a right-of-way across the farm. The farmer, on the other hand, has informed the investor that no such easement exists. Assume that both the farm and the orchard abut a public highway and that ingress and egress are afforded the investor by that highway. In an appropriate action by the investor to determine her right to use the right-of-way across the farm, she should

A) win, because the farmer had constructive notice of the easement.
B) lose, because the right-of-way was abandoned inasmuch as there never was any actual use made.
C) lose, because the easement was extinguished by merger when the farmer acquired the orchard from the rancher.
D) lose, because the easement was not in use at the time of the sale to the investor.
E) lose, because the investor has reasonable access to the public highway without using the right-of-way.
F) win, because the investor has a right to access all parts of her property.
G) lose, because the easement was not specifically mentioned in the deed between the farmer and the investor.
H) win, because the right-of-way was never officially terminated.
I) win, because the investor acquired an easement by implication.
J) win, because the original deed clearly states the existence of the right-of-way.

A farm and an orchard are adjoining tracts of land located in a county. In 2006, a farmer purchased the farm, a 10-acre tract, in fee simple absolute. The orchard, a 20-acre tract situated to the north of the farm, was owned by a rancher in fee simple absolute. A remote predecessor of the farmer had granted to a shepherd a way for egress and ingress across the farm under such terms and circumstances that an easement appurtenant to the orchard was created. This right-of-way was executed by deed and properly recorded. The shepherd, however, never made any actual use of the right-of-way. In 2010, the rancher conveyed the orchard to the farmer. The next year, the farmer conveyed the orchard by deed to an investor for a consideration of $250,000, receipt of which was acknowledged. Neither the rancher farmer deed nor the farmer  investor deed contained any reference to the easement for right-of-way. The investor has now claimed that she has a right-of-way across the farm. The farmer, on the other hand, has informed the investor that no such easement exists. Assume that both the farm and the orchard abut a public highway and that ingress and egress are afforded the investor by that highway. In an appropriate action by the investor to determine her right to use the right-of-way across the farm, she should

A) win, because the farmer had constructive notice of the easement.
B) lose, because the right-of-way was abandoned inasmuch as there never was any actual use made.
C) lose, because the easement was extinguished by merger when the farmer acquired the orchard from the rancher.
D) lose, because the easement was not in use at the time of the sale to the investor.
E) lose, because the investor has reasonable access to the public highway without using the right-of-way.
F) win, because the investor has a right to access all parts of her property.
G) lose, because the easement was not specifically mentioned in the deed between the farmer and the investor.
H) win, because the right-of-way was never officially terminated.
I) win, because the investor acquired an easement by implication.
J) win, because the original deed clearly states the existence of the right-of-way.

additional_args.task_instruction: Answer the provided question by choosing one option. Include the letter corresponding to your answer in the solution.
additional_args.input_str:
A farm and an orchard are adjoining tracts of land located in a county. In 2006, a farmer purchased the farm, a 10-acre tract, in fee simple absolute. The orchard, a 20-acre tract situated to the north of the farm, was owned by a rancher in fee simple absolute. A remote predecessor of the farmer had granted to a shepherd a way for egress and ingress across the farm under such terms and circumstances that an easement appurtenant to the orchard was created. This right-of-way was executed by deed and properly recorded. The shepherd, however, never made any actual use of the right-of-way. In 2010, the rancher conveyed the orchard to the farmer. The next year, the farmer conveyed the orchard by deed to an investor for a consideration of $250,000, receipt of which was acknowledged. Neither the rancher farmer deed nor the farmer  investor deed contained any reference to the easement for right-of-way. The investor has now claimed that she has a right-of-way across the farm. The farmer, on the other hand, has informed the investor that no such easement exists. Assume that both the farm and the orchard abut a public highway and that ingress and egress are afforded the investor by that highway. In an appropriate action by the investor to determine her right to use the right-of-way across the farm, she should

A) win, because the farmer had constructive notice of the easement.
B) lose, because the right-of-way was abandoned inasmuch as there never was any actual use made.
C) lose, because the easement was extinguished by merger when the farmer acquired the orchard from the rancher.
D) lose, because the easement was not in use at the time of the sale to the investor.
E) lose, because the investor has reasonable access to the public highway without using the right-of-way.
F) win, because the investor has a right to access all parts of her property.
G) lose, because the easement was not specifically mentioned in the deed between the farmer and the investor.
H) win, because the right-of-way was never officially terminated.
I) win, because the investor acquired an easement by implication.
J) win, because the original deed clearly states the existence of the right-of-way.

additional_args.task_instruction: Answer the provided question by choosing one option. Include the letter corresponding to your answer in the solution.
additional_args.input_str:
A farm and an orchard are adjoining tracts of land located in a county. In 2006, a farmer purchased the farm, a 10-acre tract, in fee simple absolute. The orchard, a 20-acre tract situated to the north of the farm, was owned by a rancher in fee simple absolute. A remote predecessor of the farmer had granted to a shepherd a way for egress and ingress across the farm under such terms and circumstances that an easement appurtenant to the orchard was created. This right-of-way was executed by deed and properly recorded. The shepherd, however, never made any actual use of the right-of-way. In 2010, the rancher conveyed the orchard to the farmer. The next year, the farmer conveyed the orchard by deed to an investor for a consideration of $250,000, receipt of which was acknowledged. Neither the rancher farmer deed nor the farmer  investor deed contained any reference to the easement for right-of-way. The investor has now claimed that she has a right-of-way across the farm. The farmer, on the other hand, has informed the investor that no such easement exists. Assume that both the farm and the orchard abut a public highway and that ingress and egress are afforded the investor by that highway. In an appropriate action by the investor to determine her right to use the right-of-way across the farm, she should

A) win, because the farmer had constructive notice of the easement.
B) lose, because the right-of-way was abandoned inasmuch as there never was any actual use made.
C) lose, because the easement was extinguished by merger when the farmer acquired the orchard from the rancher.
D) lose, because the easement was not in use at the time of the sale to the investor.
E) lose, because the investor has reasonable access to the public highway without using the right-of-way.
F) win, because the investor has a right to access all parts of her property.
G) lose, because the easement was not specifically mentioned in the deed between the farmer and the investor.
H) win, because the right-of-way was never officially terminated.
I) win, because the investor acquired an easement by implication.
J) win, because the original deed clearly states the existence of the right-of-way.

additional_args.input_str:
A farm and an orchard are adjoining tracts of land located in a county. In 2006, a farmer purchased the farm, a 10-acre tract, in fee simple absolute. The orchard, a 20-acre tract situated to the north of the farm, was owned by a rancher in fee simple absolute. A remote predecessor of the farmer had granted to a shepherd a way for egress and ingress across the farm under such terms and circumstances that an easement appurtenant to the orchard was created. This right-of-way was executed by deed and properly recorded. The shepherd, however, never made any actual use of the right-of-way. In 2010, the rancher conveyed the orchard to the farmer. The next year, the farmer conveyed the orchard by deed to an investor for a consideration of $250,000, receipt of which was acknowledged. Neither the rancher farmer deed nor the farmer  investor deed contained any reference to the easement for right-of-way. The investor has now claimed that she has a right-of-way across the farm. The farmer, on the other hand, has informed the investor that no such easement exists. Assume that both the farm and the orchard abut a public highway and that ingress and egress are afforded the investor by that highway. In an appropriate action by the investor to determine her right to use the right-of-way across the farm, she should

A) win, because the farmer had constructive notice of the easement.
B) lose, because the right-of-way was abandoned inasmuch as there never was any actual use made.
C) lose, because the easement was extinguished by merger when the farmer acquired the orchard from the rancher.
D) lose, because the easement was not in use at the time of the sale to the investor.
E) lose, because the investor has reasonable access to the public highway without using the right-of-way.
F) win, because the investor has a right to access all parts of her property.
G) lose, because the easement was not specifically mentioned in the deed between the farmer and the investor.
H) win, because the right-of-way was never officially terminated.
I) win, because the investor acquired an easement by implication.
J) win, because the original deed clearly states the existence of the right-of-way.

A farm and an orchard are adjoining tracts of land located in a county. In 2006, a farmer purchased the farm, a 10-acre tract, in fee simple absolute. The orchard, a 20-acre tract situated to the north of the farm, was owned by a rancher in fee simple absolute. A remote predecessor of the farmer had granted to a shepherd a way for egress and ingress across the farm under such terms and circumstances that an easement appurtenant to the orchard was created. This right-of-way was executed by deed and properly recorded. The shepherd, however, never made any actual use of the right-of-way. In 2010, the rancher conveyed the orchard to the farmer. The next year, the farmer conveyed the orchard by deed to an investor for a consideration of $250,000, receipt of which was acknowledged. Neither the rancher farmer deed nor the farmer  investor deed contained any reference to the easement for right-of-way. The investor has now claimed that she has a right-of-way across the farm. The farmer, on the other hand, has informed the investor that no such easement exists. Assume that both the farm and the orchard abut a public highway and that ingress and egress are afforded the investor by that highway. In an appropriate action by the investor to determine her right to use the right-of-way across the farm, she should

A) win, because the farmer had constructive notice of the easement.
B) lose, because the right-of-way was abandoned inasmuch as there never was any actual use made.
C) lose, because the easement was extinguished by merger when the farmer acquired the orchard from the rancher.
D) lose, because the easement was not in use at the time of the sale to the investor.
E) lose, because the investor has reasonable access to the public highway without using the right-of-way.
F) win, because the investor has a right to access all parts of her property.
G) lose, because the easement was not specifically mentioned in the deed between the farmer and the investor.
H) win, because the right-of-way was never officially terminated.
I) win, because the investor acquired an easement by implication.
J) win, because the original deed clearly states the existence of the right-of-way.

additional_args.input_str:
A farm and an orchard are adjoining tracts of land located in a county. In 2006, a farmer purchased the farm, a 10-acre tract, in fee simple absolute. The orchard, a 20-acre tract situated to the north of the farm, was owned by a rancher in fee simple absolute. A remote predecessor of the farmer had granted to a shepherd a way for egress and ingress across the farm under such terms and circumstances that an easement appurtenant to the orchard was created. This right-of-way was executed by deed and properly recorded. The shepherd, however, never made any actual use of the right-of-way. In 2010, the rancher conveyed the orchard to the farmer. The next year, the farmer conveyed the orchard by deed to an investor for a consideration of $250,000, receipt of which was acknowledged. Neither the rancher farmer deed nor the farmer  investor deed contained any reference to the easement for right-of-way. The investor has now claimed that she has a right-of-way across the farm. additional_args.input_str:
A farm and an orchard are adjoining tracts of land located in a county. In 2006, a farmer purchased the farm, a 10-acre tract, in fee simple absolute. The orchard, a 20-acre tract situated to the north of the farm, was owned by a rancher in fee simple absolute. A remote predecessor of the farmer had granted to a shepherd a way for egress and ingress across the farm under such terms and circumstances that an easement appurtenant to the orchard was created. This right-of-way was executed by deed and properly recorded. The shepherd, however, never made any actual use of the right-of-way. In 2010, the rancher conveyed the orchard to the farmer. The next year, the farmer conveyed the orchard by deed to an investor for a consideration of $250,000, receipt of which was acknowledged. Neither the rancher farmer deed nor the farmer  investor deed contained any reference to the easement for right-of-way. The investor has now claimed that she has a right-of-way across the farm. The farmer, on the other hand, has informed the investor that no such easement exists. Assume that both the farm and the orchard abut a public highway and that ingress and egress are afforded the investor by that highway. In an appropriate action by the investor to determine her right to use the right-of-way across the farm, she should

A) win, because the farmer had constructive notice of the easement.
B) lose, because the right-of-way was abandoned inasmuch as there never was any actual use made.
C) lose, because the easement was extinguished by merger when the farmer acquired the orchard from the rancher.
D) lose, because the easement was not in use at the time of the sale to the investor.
E) lose, because the investor has reasonable access to the public highway without using the right-of-way.
F) win, because the investor has a right to access all parts of her property.
G) lose, because the easement was not specifically mentioned in the deed between the farmer and the investor.
H) win, because the right-of-way was never officially terminated.
I) win, because the investor acquired an easement by implication.
J) win, because the original deed clearly states the existence of the right-of-way.

B) lose, because the right-of-way was abandoned inasmuch as there never was any actual use made.
C) lose, because the easement was extinguished by merger when the farmer acquired the orchard from the rancher.
D) lose, because the easement was not in use at the time of the sale to the investor.

H) win, because the right-of-way was never officially terminated.
I) win, because the investor acquired an easement by implication.
J) win, because the original deed clearly states the existence of the right-of-way.

additional_args.input_str:
A farm and an orchard are adjoining tracts of land located in a county. In 2006, a farmer purchased the farm, a 10-acre tract, in fee simple absolute. The orchard, a 20-acre tract situated to the north of the farm, was owned by a rancher in fee simple absolute. A remote predecessor of the farmer had granted to a shepherd a way for egress and ingress across the farm under such terms and circumstances that an easement appurtenant to the orchard was created. This right-of-way was executed by deed and properly recorded. The shepherd, however, never made any actual use of the right-of-way. In 2010, the rancher conveyed the orchard to the farmer. The next year, the farmer conveyed the orchard by deed to an investor for a consideration of $250,000, receipt of which was acknowledged. Neither the rancher farmer deed nor the farmer  investor deed contained any reference to the easement for right-of-way. The investor has now claimed that she has a right-of-way across the farm. The farmer, on the other hand, has informed the investor that no such easement exists. Assume that both the farm and the orchard abut a public highway and that ingress and egress are afforded the investor by that highway. In an appropriate action by the investor to determine her right to use the right-of-way across the farm, she should

A) win, because the farmer had constructive notice of the easement.
B) lose, because the right-of-way was abandoned inasmuch as there never was any actual use made.
C) lose, because the easement was extinguished by merger when the farmer acquired the orchard from the rancher.
D) lose, because the easement was not in use at the time of the sale to the investor.
E) lose, because the investor has reasonable access to the public highway without using the right-of-way.
F) win, because the investor has a right to access all parts of her property.
G) lose, because the easement was not specifically mentioned in the deed between the farmer and the investor.
H) win, because the right-of-way was never officially terminated.
I) win, because the investor acquired an easement by implication.
J) win, because the original deed clearly states the existence of the right-of-way.

A farm and an orchard are adjoining tracts of land located in a county. In 2006, a farmer purchased the farm, a 10-acre tract, in fee simple absolute. The orchard, a 20-acre tract situated to the north of the farm, was owned by a rancher in fee simple absolute. A remote predecessor of the farmer had granted to a shepherd a way for egress and ingress across the farm under such terms and circumstances that an easement appurtenant to the orchard was created. This right-of-way was executed by deed and properly recorded. The shepherd, however, never made any actual use of the right-of-way. In 2010, the rancher conveyed the orchard to the farmer. The next year, the farmer conveyed the orchard by deed to an investor for a consideration of $250,000, receipt of which was acknowledged. Neither the rancher farmer deed nor the farmer  investor deed contained any reference to the easement for right-of-way. The investor has now claimed that she has a right-of-way across the farm. The farmer, on the other hand, has informed the investor that no such easement exists. Assume that both the farm and the orchard abut a public highway and that ingress and egress are afforded the investor by that highway. A) win, because the farmer had constructive notice of the easement.
B) lose, because the right-of-way was abandoned inasmuch as there never was any actual use made.
C) lose, because the easement was extinguished by merger when the farmer acquired the orchard from the rancher.
D) lose, because the easement was not in use at the time of the sale to the investor.

H) win, because the right-of-way was never officially terminated.
I) win, because the investor acquired an easement by implication.
J) win, because the original deed clearly states the existence of the right-of-way.

A farm and an orchard are adjoining tracts of land located in a county. In 2006, a farmer purchased the farm, a 10-acre tract, in fee simple absolute. The orchard, a 20-acre tract situated to the north of the farm, was owned by a rancher in fee simple absolute. A remote predecessor of the farmer had granted to a shepherd a way for egress and ingress across the farm under such terms and circumstances that an easement appurtenant to the orchard was created. This right-of-way was executed by deed and properly recorded. The shepherd, however, never made any actual use of the right-of-way. In 2010, the rancher conveyed the orchard to the farmer. The next year, the farmer conveyed the orchard by deed to an investor for a consideration of $250,000, receipt of which was acknowledged. Neither the rancher farmer deed nor the farmer  investor deed contained any reference to the easement for right-of-way. The investor has now claimed that she has a right-of-way across the farm. The farmer, on the other hand, has informed the investor that no such easement exists. Assume that both the farm and the orchard abut a public highway and that ingress and egress are afforded the investor by that highway. In an appropriate action by the investor to determine her right to use the right-of-way across the farm, she should

A) win, because the farmer had constructive notice of the easement.
B) lose, because the right-of-way was abandoned inasmuch as there never was any actual use made.
C) lose, because the easement was extinguished by merger when the farmer acquired the orchard from the rancher.
D) lose, because the easement was not in use at the time of the sale to the investor.
E) lose, because the investor has reasonable access to the public highway without using the right-of-way.
F) win, because the investor has a right to access all parts of her property.
G) lose, because the easement was not specifically mentioned in the deed between the farmer and the investor.
H) win, because the right-of-way was never officially terminated.
I) win, because the investor acquired an easement by implication.
J) win, because the original deed clearly states the existence of the right-of-way.

A remote predecessor of the farmer had granted to a shepherd a way for egress and ingress across the farm under such terms and circumstances that an easement appurtenant to the orchard was created. This right-of-way was executed by deed and properly recorded. The shepherd, however, never made any actual use of the right-of-way. In 2010, the rancher conveyed the orchard to the farmer. The next year, the farmer conveyed the orchard by deed to an investor for a consideration of $250,000, receipt of which was acknowledged. Neither the rancher farmer deed nor the farmer  investor deed contained any reference to the easement for right-of-way. The investor has now claimed that she has a right-of-way across the farm. B) lose, because the right-of-way was abandoned inasmuch as there never was any actual use made.
C) lose, because the easement was extinguished by merger when the farmer acquired the orchard from the rancher.
D) lose, because the easement was not in use at the time of the sale to the investor.
E) lose, because the investor has reasonable access to the public highway without using the right-of-way.
F) win, because the investor has a right to access all parts of her property.
G) lose, because the easement was not specifically mentioned in the deed between the farmer and the investor.
H) win, because the right-of-way was never officially terminated.
I) win, because the investor acquired an easement by implication.
J) win, because the original deed clearly states the existence of the right-of-way.

additional_args.input_str:
A farm and an orchard are adjoining tracts of land located in a county. In 2006, a farmer purchased the farm, a 10-acre tract, in fee simple absolute. The orchard, a 20-acre tract situated to the north of the farm, was owned by a rancher in fee simple absolute. A remote predecessor of the farmer had granted to a shepherd a way for egress and ingress across the farm under such terms and circumstances that an easement appurtenant to the orchard was created. This right-of-way was executed by deed and properly recorded. The shepherd, however, never made any actual use of the right-of-way. In 2010, the rancher conveyed the orchard to the farmer. The next year, the farmer conveyed the orchard by deed to an investor for a consideration of $250,000, receipt of which was acknowledged. Neither the rancher farmer deed nor the farmer  investor deed contained any reference to the easement for right-of-way. The investor has now claimed that she has a right-of-way across the farm. The farmer, on the other hand, has informed the investor that no such easement exists. Assume that both the farm and the orchard abut a public highway and that ingress and egress are afforded the investor by that highway. In an appropriate action by the investor to determine her right to use the right-of-way across the farm, she should

A) win, because the farmer had constructive notice of the easement.
B) lose, because the right-of-way was abandoned inasmuch as there never was any actual use made.
C) lose, because the easement was extinguished by merger when the farmer acquired the orchard from the rancher.
D) lose, because the easement was not in use at the time of the sale to the investor.
E) lose, because the investor has reasonable access to the public highway without using the right-of-way.
F) win, because the investor has a right to access all parts of her property.
G) lose, because the easement was not specifically mentioned in the deed between the farmer and the investor.
H) win, because the right-of-way was never officially terminated.
I) win, because the investor acquired an easement by implication.
J) win, because the original deed clearly states the existence of the right-of-way.

A farm and an orchard are adjoining tracts of land located in a county. In 2006, a farmer purchased the farm, a 10-acre tract, in fee simple absolute. The orchard, a 20-acre tract situated to the north of the farm, was owned by a rancher in fee simple absolute. A remote predecessor of the farmer had granted to a shepherd a way for egress and ingress across the farm under such terms and circumstances that an easement appurtenant to the orchard was created. This right-of-way was executed by deed and properly recorded. The shepherd, however, never made any actual use of the right-of-way. In 2010, the rancher conveyed the orchard to the farmer. The next year, the farmer conveyed the orchard by deed to an investor for a consideration of $250,000, receipt of which was acknowledged. Neither the rancher farmer deed nor the farmer  investor deed contained any reference to the easement for right-of-way. The investor has now claimed that she has a right-of-way across the farm. The farmer, on the other hand, has informed the investor that no such easement exists. Assume that both the farm and the orchard abut a public highway and that ingress and egress are afforded the investor by that highway. In an appropriate action by the investor to determine her right to use the right-of-way across the farm, she should

A) win, because the farmer had constructive notice of the easement.
B) lose, because the right-of-way was abandoned inasmuch as there never was any actual use made.
C) lose, because the easement was extinguished by merger when the farmer acquired the orchard from the rancher.
D) lose, because the easement was not in use at the time of the sale to the investor.
E) lose, because the investor has reasonable access to the public highway without using the right-of-way.
F) win, because the investor has a right to access all parts of her property.
G) lose, because the easement was not specifically mentioned in the deed between the farmer and the investor.
H) win, because the right-of-way was never officially terminated.
I) win, because the investor acquired an easement by implication.
J) win, because the original deed clearly states the existence of the right-of-way.

additional_args.input_str:
A farm and an orchard are adjoining tracts of land located in a county. In 2006, a farmer purchased the farm, a 10-acre tract, in fee simple absolute. The orchard, a 20-acre tract situated to the north of the farm, was owned by a rancher in fee simple absolute. A remote predecessor of the farmer had granted to a shepherd a way for egress and ingress across the farm under such terms and circumstances that an easement appurtenant to the orchard was created. This right-of-way was executed by deed and properly recorded. The shepherd, however, never made any actual use of the right-of-way. In 2010, the rancher conveyed the orchard to the farmer. The next year, the farmer conveyed the orchard by deed to an investor for a consideration of $250,000, receipt of which was acknowledged. Neither the rancher farmer deed nor the farmer  investor deed contained any reference to the easement for right-of-way. The investor has now claimed that she has a right-of-way across the farm. The farmer, on the other hand, has informed the investor that no such easement exists. Assume that both the farm and the orchard abut a public highway and that ingress and egress are afforded the investor by that highway. In an appropriate action by the investor to determine her right to use the right-of-way across the farm, she should

A) win, because the farmer had constructive notice of the easement.
B) lose, because the right-of-way was abandoned inasmuch as there never was any actual use made.
C) lose, because the easement was extinguished by merger when the farmer acquired the orchard from the rancher.
D) lose, because the easement was not in use at the time of the sale to the investor.
E) lose, because the investor has reasonable access to the public highway without using the right-of-way.
F) win, because the investor has a right to access all parts of her property.
G) lose, because the easement was not specifically mentioned in the deed between the farmer and the investor.
H) win, because the right-of-way was never officially terminated.
I) win, because the investor acquired an easement by implication.
J) win, because the original deed clearly states the existence of the right-of-way.

additional_args.task_instruction: Answer the provided question by choosing one option. Include the letter corresponding to your answer in the solution.
additional_args.input_str:
A farm and an orchard are adjoining tracts of land located in a county. In 2006, a farmer purchased the farm, a 10-acre tract, in fee simple absolute. The orchard, a 20-acre tract situated to the north of the farm, was owned by a rancher in fee simple absolute. A remote predecessor of the farmer had granted to a shepherd a way for egress and ingress across the farm under such terms and circumstances that an easement appurtenant to the orchard was created. This right-of-way was executed by deed and properly recorded. The shepherd, however, never made any actual use of the right-of-way. In 2010, the rancher conveyed the orchard to the farmer. The next year, the farmer conveyed the orchard by deed to an investor for a consideration of $250,000, receipt of which was acknowledged. Neither the rancher farmer deed nor the farmer  investor deed contained any reference to the easement for right-of-way. The investor has now claimed that she has a right-of-way across the farm. The farmer, on the other hand, has informed the investor that no such easement exists. Assume that both the farm and the orchard abut a public highway and that ingress and egress are afforded the investor by that highway. In an appropriate action by the investor to determine her right to use the right-of-way across the farm, she should

A) win, because the farmer had constructive notice of the easement.
B) lose, because the right-of-way was abandoned inasmuch as there never was any actual use made.
C) lose, because the easement was extinguished by merger when the farmer acquired the orchard from the rancher.
D) lose, because the easement was not in use at the time of the sale to the investor.
E) lose, because the investor has reasonable access to the public highway without using the right-of-way.
F) win, because the investor has a right to access all parts of her property.
G) lose, because the easement was not specifically mentioned in the deed between the farmer and the investor.
H) win, because the right-of-way was never officially terminated.
I) win, because the investor acquired an easement by implication.
J) win, because the original deed clearly states the existence of the right-of-way.

additional_args.input_str:
A farm and an orchard are adjoining tracts of land located in a county. In 2006, a farmer purchased the farm, a 10-acre tract, in fee simple absolute. The orchard, a 20-acre tract situated to the north of the farm, was owned by a rancher in fee simple absolute. A remote predecessor of the farmer had granted to a shepherd a way for egress and ingress across the farm under such terms and circumstances that an easement appurtenant to the orchard was created. This right-of-way was executed by deed and properly recorded. The shepherd, however, never made any actual use of the right-of-way. In 2010, the rancher conveyed the orchard to the farmer. The next year, the farmer conveyed the orchard by deed to an investor for a consideration of $250,000, receipt of which was acknowledged. Neither the rancher farmer deed nor the farmer  investor deed contained any reference to the easement for right-of-way. The investor has now claimed that she has a right-of-way across the farm. The farmer, on the other hand, has informed the investor that no such easement exists. Assume that both the farm and the orchard abut a public highway and that ingress and egress are afforded the investor by that highway. In an appropriate action by the investor to determine her right to use the right-of-way across the farm, she should

A) win, because the farmer had constructive notice of the easement.
B) lose, because the right-of-way was abandoned inasmuch as there never was any actual use made.
C) lose, because the easement was extinguished by merger when the farmer acquired the orchard from the rancher.
D) lose, because the easement was not in use at the time of the sale to the investor.
E) lose, because the investor has reasonable access to the public highway without using the right-of-way.
F) win, because the investor has a right to access all parts of her property.
G) lose, because the easement was not specifically mentioned in the deed between the farmer and the investor.
H) win, because the right-of-way was never officially terminated.
I) win, because the investor acquired an easement by implication.
J) win, because the original deed clearly states the existence of the right-of-way.

additional_args.input_str:
A farm and an orchard are adjoining tracts of land located in a county. In 2006, a farmer purchased the farm, a 10-acre tract, in fee simple absolute. The orchard, a 20-acre tract situated to the north of the farm, was owned by a rancher in fee simple absolute. A remote predecessor of the farmer had granted to a shepherd a way for egress and ingress across the farm under such terms and circumstances that an easement appurtenant to the orchard was created. This right-of-way was executed by deed and properly recorded. The shepherd, however, never made any actual use of the right-of-way. In 2010, the rancher conveyed the orchard to the farmer. The next year, the farmer conveyed the orchard by deed to an investor for a consideration of $250,000, receipt of which was acknowledged. Neither the rancher farmer deed nor the farmer  investor deed contained any reference to the easement for right-of-way. The investor has now claimed that she has a right-of-way across the farm. The farmer, on the other hand, has informed the investor that no such easement exists. Assume that both the farm and the orchard abut a public highway and that ingress and egress are afforded the investor by that highway. In an appropriate action by the investor to determine her right to use the right-of-way across the farm, she should

A) win, because the farmer had constructive notice of the easement.
B) lose, because the right-of-way was abandoned inasmuch as there never was any actual use made.
C) lose, because the easement was extinguished by merger when the farmer acquired the orchard from the rancher.
D) lose, because the easement was not in use at the time of the sale to the investor.
E) lose, because the investor has reasonable access to the public highway without using the right-of-way.
F) win, because the investor has a right to access all parts of her property.
G) lose, because the easement was not specifically mentioned in the deed between the farmer and the investor.
H) win, because the right-of-way was never officially terminated.
I) win, because the investor acquired an easement by implication.
J) win, because the original deed clearly states the existence of the right-of-way.

5. **Easement Continuance**: An easement appurtenant continues with the land and is transferred with it, regardless of whether it is mentioned in the deed, as long as the easement was properly recorded when it was created.

A farm and an orchard are adjoining tracts of land located in a county. In 2006, a farmer purchased the farm, a 10-acre tract, in fee simple absolute. The orchard, a 20-acre tract situated to the north of the farm, was owned by a rancher in fee simple absolute. A remote predecessor of the farmer had granted to a shepherd a way for egress and ingress across the farm under such terms and circumstances that an easement appurtenant to the orchard was created. This right-of-way was executed by deed and properly recorded. The shepherd, however, never made any actual use of the right-of-way. In 2010, the rancher conveyed the orchard to the farmer. The next year, the farmer conveyed the orchard by deed to an investor for a consideration of $250,000, receipt of which was acknowledged. Neither the rancher farmer deed nor the farmer  investor deed contained any reference to the easement for right-of-way. The investor has now claimed that she has a right-of-way across the farm. The farmer, on the other hand, has informed the investor that no such easement exists. Assume that both the farm and the orchard abut a public highway and that ingress and egress are afforded the investor by that highway. In an appropriate action by the investor to determine her right to use the right-of-way across the farm, she should

A) win, because the farmer had constructive notice of the easement.
B) lose, because the right-of-way was abandoned inasmuch as there never was any actual use made.
C) lose, because the easement was extinguished by merger when the farmer acquired the orchard from the rancher.
D) lose, because the easement was not in use at the time of the sale to the investor.
E) lose, because the investor has reasonable access to the public highway without using the right-of-way.
F) win, because the investor has a right to access all parts of her property.
G) lose, because the easement was not specifically mentioned in the deed between the farmer and the investor.
H) win, because the right-of-way was never officially terminated.
I) win, because the investor acquired an easement by implication.
J) win, because the original deed clearly states the existence of the right-of-way.

additional_args.input_str:
A farm and an orchard are adjoining tracts of land located in a county. In 2006, a farmer purchased the farm, a 10-acre tract, in fee simple absolute. The orchard, a 20-acre tract situated to the north of the farm, was owned by a rancher in fee simple absolute. A remote predecessor of the farmer had granted to a shepherd a way for egress and ingress across the farm under such terms and circumstances that an easement appurtenant to the orchard was created. This right-of-way was executed by deed and properly recorded. The shepherd, however, never made any actual use of the right-of-way. In 2010, the rancher conveyed the orchard to the farmer. The next year, the farmer conveyed the orchard by deed to an investor for a consideration of $250,000, receipt of which was acknowledged. Neither the rancher farmer deed nor the farmer  investor deed contained any reference to the easement for right-of-way. The investor has now claimed that she has a right-of-way across the farm. The farmer, on the other hand, has informed the investor that no such easement exists. Assume that both the farm and the orchard abut a public highway and that ingress and egress are afforded the investor by that highway. In an appropriate action by the investor to determine her right to use the right-of-way across the farm, she should

A) win, because the farmer had constructive notice of the easement.
B) lose, because the right-of-way was abandoned inasmuch as there never was any actual use made.
C) lose, because the easement was extinguished by merger when the farmer acquired the orchard from the rancher.
D) lose, because the easement was not in use at the time of the sale to the investor.
E) lose, because the investor has reasonable access to the public highway without using the right-of-way.
F) win, because the investor has a right to access all parts of her property.
G) lose, because the easement was not specifically mentioned in the deed between the farmer and the investor.
H) win, because the right-of-way was never officially terminated.
I) win, because the investor acquired an easement by implication.
J) win, because the original deed clearly states the existence of the right-of-way.

B) lose, because the right-of-way was abandoned inasmuch as there never was any actual use made.

additional_args.input_str:
A farm and an orchard are adjoining tracts of land located in a county. In 2006, a farmer purchased the farm, a 10-acre tract, in fee simple absolute. The orchard, a 20-acre tract situated to the north of the farm, was owned by a rancher in fee simple absolute. A remote predecessor of the farmer had granted to a shepherd a way for egress and ingress across the farm under such terms and circumstances that an easement appurtenant to the orchard was created. This right-of-way was executed by deed and properly recorded. The shepherd, however, never made any actual use of the right-of-way. In 2010, the rancher conveyed the orchard to the farmer. The next year, the farmer conveyed the orchard by deed to an investor for a consideration of $250,000, receipt of which was acknowledged. Neither the rancher farmer deed nor the farmer  investor deed contained any reference to the easement for right-of-way. The investor has now claimed that she has a right-of-way across the farm. The farmer, on the other hand, has informed the investor that no such easement exists. Assume that both the farm and the orchard abut a public highway and that ingress and egress are afforded the investor by that highway. In an appropriate action by the investor to determine her right to use the right-of-way across the farm, she should

A) win, because the farmer had constructive notice of the easement.
B) lose, because the right-of-way was abandoned inasmuch as there never was any actual use made.
C) lose, because the easement was extinguished by merger when the farmer acquired the orchard from the rancher.
D) lose, because the easement was not in use at the time of the sale to the investor.
E) lose, because the investor has reasonable access to the public highway without using the right-of-way.
F) win, because the investor has a right to access all parts of her property.
G) lose, because the easement was not specifically mentioned in the deed between the farmer and the investor.
H) win, because the right-of-way was never officially terminated.
I) win, because the investor acquired an easement by implication.
J) win, because the original deed clearly states the existence of the right-of-way.

A farm and an orchard are adjoining tracts of land located in a county. In 2006, a farmer purchased the farm, a 10-acre tract, in fee simple absolute. The orchard, a 20-acre tract situated to the north of the farm, was owned by a rancher in fee simple absolute. A remote predecessor of the farmer had granted to a shepherd a way for egress and ingress across the farm under such terms and circumstances that an easement appurtenant to the orchard was created. This right-of-way was executed by deed and properly recorded. The shepherd, however, never made any actual use of the right-of-way. In 2010, the rancher conveyed the orchard to the farmer. The next year, the farmer conveyed the orchard by deed to an investor for a consideration of $250,000, receipt of which was acknowledged. Neither the rancher farmer deed nor the farmer  investor deed contained any reference to the easement for right-of-way. The investor has now claimed that she has a right-of-way across the farm. The farmer, on the other hand, has informed the investor that no such easement exists. Assume that both the farm and the orchard abut a public highway and that ingress and egress are afforded the investor by that highway. In an appropriate action by the investor to determine her right to use the right-of-way across the farm, she should

A) win, because the farmer had constructive notice of the easement.
B) lose, because the right-of-way was abandoned inasmuch as there never was any actual use made.
C) lose, because the easement was extinguished by merger when the farmer acquired the orchard from the rancher.
D) lose, because the easement was not in use at the time of the sale to the investor.
E) lose, because the investor has reasonable access to the public highway without using the right-of-way.
F) win, because the investor has a right to access all parts of her property.
G) lose, because the easement was not specifically mentioned in the deed between the farmer and the investor.
H) win, because the right-of-way was never officially terminated.
I) win, because the investor acquired an easement by implication.
J) win, because the original deed clearly states the existence of the right-of-way.

additional_args.input_str:
A farm and an orchard are adjoining tracts of land located in a county. In 2006, a farmer purchased the farm, a 10-acre tract, in fee simple absolute. The orchard, a 20-acre tract situated to the north of the farm, was owned by a rancher in fee simple absolute. A remote predecessor of the farmer had granted to a shepherd a way for egress and ingress across the farm under such terms and circumstances that an easement appurtenant to the orchard was created. This right-of-way was executed by deed and properly recorded. The shepherd, however, never made any actual use of the right-of-way. In 2010, the rancher conveyed the orchard to the farmer. The next year, the farmer conveyed the orchard by deed to an investor for a consideration of $250,000, receipt of which was acknowledged. Neither the rancher farmer deed nor the farmer  investor deed contained any reference to the easement for right-of-way. The investor has now claimed that she has a right-of-way across the farm. The farmer, on the other hand, has informed the investor that no such easement exists. Assume that both the farm and the orchard abut a public highway and that ingress and egress are afforded the investor by that highway. In an appropriate action by the investor to determine her right to use the right-of-way across the farm, she should

A) win, because the farmer had constructive notice of the easement.
B) lose, because the right-of-way was abandoned inasmuch as there never was any actual use made.
C) lose, because the easement was extinguished by merger when the farmer acquired the orchard from the rancher.
D) lose, because the easement was not in use at the time of the sale to the investor.
E) lose, because the investor has reasonable access to the public highway without using the right-of-way.
F) win, because the investor has a right to access all parts of her property.
G) lose, because the easement was not specifically mentioned in the deed between the farmer and the investor.
H) win, because the right-of-way was never officially terminated.
I) win, because the investor acquired an easement by implication.
J) win, because the original deed clearly states the existence of the right-of-way.

additional_args.input_str:
A farm and an orchard are adjoining tracts of land located in a county. In 2006, a farmer purchased the farm, a 10-acre tract, in fee simple absolute. The orchard, a 20-acre tract situated to the north of the farm, was owned by a rancher in fee simple absolute. A remote predecessor of the farmer had granted to a shepherd a way for egress and ingress across the farm under such terms and circumstances that an easement appurtenant to the orchard was created. This right-of-way was executed by deed and properly recorded. The shepherd, however, never made any actual use of the right-of-way. In 2010, the rancher conveyed the orchard to the farmer. The next year, the farmer conveyed the orchard by deed to an investor for a consideration of $250,000, receipt of which was acknowledged. Neither the rancher farmer deed nor the farmer  investor deed contained any reference to the easement for right-of-way. The investor has now claimed that she has a right-of-way across the farm. The farmer, on the other hand, has informed the investor that no such easement exists. Assume that both the farm and the orchard abut a public highway and that ingress and egress are afforded the investor by that highway. In an appropriate action by the investor to determine her right to use the right-of-way across the farm, she should

A) win, because the farmer had constructive notice of the easement.
B) lose, because the right-of-way was abandoned inasmuch as there never was any actual use made.
C) lose, because the easement was extinguished by merger when the farmer acquired the orchard from the rancher.
D) lose, because the easement was not in use at the time of the sale to the investor.
E) lose, because the investor has reasonable access to the public highway without using the right-of-way.
F) win, because the investor has a right to access all parts of her property.
G) lose, because the easement was not specifically mentioned in the deed between the farmer and the investor.
H) win, because the right-of-way was never officially terminated.
I) win, because the investor acquired an easement by implication.
J) win, because the original deed clearly states the existence of the right-of-way.

additional_args.input_str:
A farm and an orchard are adjoining tracts of land located in a county. In 2006, a farmer purchased the farm, a 10-acre tract, in fee simple absolute. The orchard, a 20-acre tract situated to the north of the farm, was owned by a rancher in fee simple absolute. A remote predecessor of the farmer had granted to a shepherd a way for egress and ingress across the farm under such terms and circumstances that an easement appurtenant to the orchard was created. This right-of-way was executed by deed and properly recorded. The shepherd, however, never made any actual use of the right-of-way. In 2010, the rancher conveyed the orchard to the farmer. The next year, the farmer conveyed the orchard by deed to an investor for a consideration of $250,000, receipt of which was acknowledged. Neither the rancher farmer deed nor the farmer  investor deed contained any reference to the easement for right-of-way. The investor has now claimed that she has a right-of-way across the farm. The farmer, on the other hand, has informed the investor that no such easement exists. Assume that both the farm and the orchard abut a public highway and that ingress and egress are afforded the investor by that highway. In an appropriate action by the investor to determine her right to use the right-of-way across the farm, she should

A) win, because the farmer had constructive notice of the easement.
B) lose, because the right-of-way was abandoned inasmuch as there never was any actual use made.
C) lose, because the easement was extinguished by merger when the farmer acquired the orchard from the rancher.
D) lose, because the easement was not in use at the time of the sale to the investor.
E) lose, because the investor has reasonable access to the public highway without using the right-of-way.
F) win, because the investor has a right to access all parts of her property.
G) lose, because the easement was not specifically mentioned in the deed between the farmer and the investor.
H) win, because the right-of-way was never officially terminated.
I) win, because the investor acquired an easement by implication.
J) win, because the original deed clearly states the existence of the right-of-way.

additional_args.input_str:
A farm and an orchard are adjoining tracts of land located in a county. In 2006, a farmer purchased the farm, a 10-acre tract, in fee simple absolute. The orchard, a 20-acre tract situated to the north of the farm, was owned by a rancher in fee simple absolute. A remote predecessor of the farmer had granted to a shepherd a way for egress and ingress across the farm under such terms and circumstances that an easement appurtenant to the orchard was created. This right-of-way was executed by deed and properly recorded. The shepherd, however, never made any actual use of the right-of-way. In 2010, the rancher conveyed the orchard to the farmer. The next year, the farmer conveyed the orchard by deed to an investor for a consideration of $250,000, receipt of which was acknowledged. Neither the rancher farmer deed nor the farmer  investor deed contained any reference to the easement for right-of-way. The investor has now claimed that she has a right-of-way across the farm. The farmer, on the other hand, has informed the investor that no such easement exists. Assume that both the farm and the orchard abut a public highway and that ingress and egress are afforded the investor by that highway. In an appropriate action by the investor to determine her right to use the right-of-way across the farm, she should

A) win, because the farmer had constructive notice of the easement.
B) lose, because the right-of-way was abandoned inasmuch as there never was any actual use made.
C) lose, because the easement was extinguished by merger when the farmer acquired the orchard from the rancher.
D) lose, because the easement was not in use at the time of the sale to the investor.
E) lose, because the investor has reasonable access to the public highway without using the right-of-way.
F) win, because the investor has a right to access all parts of her property.
G) lose, because the easement was not specifically mentioned in the deed between the farmer and the investor.
H) win, because the right-of-way was never officially terminated.
I) win, because the investor acquired an easement by implication.
J) win, because the original deed clearly states the existence of the right-of-way.

additional_args.task_instruction: Answer the provided question by choosing one option. Include the letter corresponding to your answer in the solution.
additional_args.input_str:
A farm and an orchard are adjoining tracts of land located in a county. In 2006, a farmer purchased the farm, a 10-acre tract, in fee simple absolute. The orchard, a 20-acre tract situated to the north of the farm, was owned by a rancher in fee simple absolute. A remote predecessor of the farmer had granted to a shepherd a way for egress and ingress across the farm under such terms and circumstances that an easement appurtenant to the orchard was created. This right-of-way was executed by deed and properly recorded. The shepherd, however, never made any actual use of the right-of-way. In 2010, the rancher conveyed the orchard to the farmer. The next year, the farmer conveyed the orchard by deed to an investor for a consideration of $250,000, receipt of which was acknowledged. Neither the rancher farmer deed nor the farmer  investor deed contained any reference to the easement for right-of-way. The investor has now claimed that she has a right-of-way across the farm. The farmer, on the other hand, has informed the investor that no such easement exists. Assume that both the farm and the orchard abut a public highway and that ingress and egress are afforded the investor by that highway. In an appropriate action by the investor to determine her right to use the right-of-way across the farm, she should

A) win, because the farmer had constructive notice of the easement.
B) lose, because the right-of-way was abandoned inasmuch as there never was any actual use made.
C) lose, because the easement was extinguished by merger when the farmer acquired the orchard from the rancher.
D) lose, because the easement was not in use at the time of the sale to the investor.
E) lose, because the investor has reasonable access to the public highway without using the right-of-way.
F) win, because the investor has a right to access all parts of her property.
G) lose, because the easement was not specifically mentioned in the deed between the farmer and the investor.
H) win, because the right-of-way was never officially terminated.
I) win, because the investor acquired an easement by implication.
J) win, because the original deed clearly states the existence of the right-of-way.

additional_args.input_str:
A farm and an orchard are adjoining tracts of land located in a county. In 2006, a farmer purchased the farm, a 10-acre tract, in fee simple absolute. The orchard, a 20-acre tract situated to the north of the farm, was owned by a rancher in fee simple absolute. A remote predecessor of the farmer had granted to a shepherd a way for egress and ingress across the farm under such terms and circumstances that an easement appurtenant to the orchard was created. This right-of-way was executed by deed and properly recorded. The shepherd, however, never made any actual use of the right-of-way. In 2010, the rancher conveyed the orchard to the farmer. The next year, the farmer conveyed the orchard by deed to an investor for a consideration of $250,000, receipt of which was acknowledged. Neither the rancher farmer deed nor the farmer  investor deed contained any reference to the easement for right-of-way. The investor has now claimed that she has a right-of-way across the farm. The farmer, on the other hand, has informed the investor that no such easement exists. Assume that both the farm and the orchard abut a public highway and that ingress and egress are afforded the investor by that highway. In an appropriate action by the investor to determine her right to use the right-of-way across the farm, she should

A) win, because the farmer had constructive notice of the easement.
B) lose, because the right-of-way was abandoned inasmuch as there never was any actual use made.
C) lose, because the easement was extinguished by merger when the farmer acquired the orchard from the rancher.
D) lose, because the easement was not in use at the time of the sale to the investor.
E) lose, because the investor has reasonable access to the public highway without using the right-of-way.
F) win, because the investor has a right to access all parts of her property.
G) lose, because the easement was not specifically mentioned in the deed between the farmer and the investor.
H) win, because the right-of-way was never officially terminated.
I) win, because the investor acquired an easement by implication.
J) win, because the original deed clearly states the existence of the right-of-way.

A farm and an orchard are adjoining tracts of land located in a county. In 2006, a farmer purchased the farm, a 10-acre tract, in fee simple absolute. The orchard, a 20-acre tract situated to the north of the farm, was owned by a rancher in fee simple absolute. A remote predecessor of the farmer had granted to a shepherd a way for egress and ingress across the farm under such terms and circumstances that an easement appurtenant to the orchard was created. This right-of-way was executed by deed and properly recorded. The shepherd, however, never made any actual use of the right-of-way. In 2010, the rancher conveyed the orchard to the farmer. The next year, the farmer conveyed the orchard by deed to an investor for a consideration of $250,000, receipt of which was acknowledged. Neither the rancher farmer deed nor the farmer  investor deed contained any reference to the easement for right-of-way. The investor has now claimed that she has a right-of-way across the farm. The farmer, on the other hand, has informed the investor that no such easement exists. A) win, because the farmer had constructive notice of the easement.
B) lose, because the right-of-way was abandoned inasmuch as there never was any actual use made.
C) lose, because the easement was extinguished by merger when the farmer acquired the orchard from the rancher.
D) lose, because the easement was not in use at the time of the sale to the investor.
E) lose, because the investor has reasonable access to the public highway without using the right-of-way.
F) win, because the investor has a right to access all parts of her property.
G) lose, because the easement was not specifically mentioned in the deed between the farmer and the investor.
H) win, because the right-of-way was never officially terminated.
I) win, because the investor acquired an easement by implication.
J) win, because the original deed clearly states the existence of the right-of-way.

A farm and an orchard are adjoining tracts of land located in a county. In 2006, a farmer purchased the farm, a 10-acre tract, in fee simple absolute. The orchard, a 20-acre tract situated to the north of the farm, was owned by a rancher in fee simple absolute. A remote predecessor of the farmer had granted to a shepherd a way for egress and ingress across the farm under such terms and circumstances that an easement appurtenant to the orchard was created. This right-of-way was executed by deed and properly recorded. The shepherd, however, never made any actual use of the right-of-way. In 2010, the rancher conveyed the orchard to the farmer. The next year, the farmer conveyed the orchard by deed to an investor for a consideration of $250,000, receipt of which was acknowledged. Neither the rancher farmer deed nor the farmer  investor deed contained any reference to the easement for right-of-way. The investor has now claimed that she has a right-of-way across the farm. The farmer, on the other hand, has informed the investor that no such easement exists. Assume that both the farm and the orchard abut a public highway and that ingress and egress are afforded the investor by that highway. In an appropriate action by the investor to determine her right to use the right-of-way across the farm, she should

A) win, because the farmer had constructive notice of the easement.
B) lose, because the right-of-way was abandoned inasmuch as there never was any actual use made.
C) lose, because the easement was extinguished by merger when the farmer acquired the orchard from the rancher.
D) lose, because the easement was not in use at the time of the sale to the investor.
E) lose, because the investor has reasonable access to the public highway without using the right-of-way.
F) win, because the investor has a right to access all parts of her property.
G) lose, because the easement was not specifically mentioned in the deed between the farmer and the investor.
H) win, because the right-of-way was never officially terminated.
I) win, because the investor acquired an easement by implication.
J) win, because the original deed clearly states the existence of the right-of-way.

A farm and an orchard are adjoining tracts of land located in a county. In 2006, a farmer purchased the farm, a 10-acre tract, in fee simple absolute. The orchard, a 20-acre tract situated to the north of the farm, was owned by a rancher in fee simple absolute. A remote predecessor of the farmer had granted to a shepherd a way for egress and ingress across the farm under such terms and circumstances that an easement appurtenant to the orchard was created. This right-of-way was executed by deed and properly recorded. The shepherd, however, never made any actual use of the right-of-way. In 2010, the rancher conveyed the orchard to the farmer. The next year, the farmer conveyed the orchard by deed to an investor for a consideration of $250,000, receipt of which was acknowledged. Neither the rancher farmer deed nor the farmer  investor deed contained any reference to the easement for right-of-way. The investor has now claimed that she has a right-of-way across the farm. The farmer, on the other hand, has informed the investor that no such easement exists. Assume that both the farm and the orchard abut a public highway and that ingress and egress are afforded the investor by that highway. In an appropriate action by the investor to determine her right to use the right-of-way across the farm, she should

A) win, because the farmer had constructive notice of the easement.
B) lose, because the right-of-way was abandoned inasmuch as there never was any actual use made.
C) lose, because the easement was extinguished by merger when the farmer acquired the orchard from the rancher.
D) lose, because the easement was not in use at the time of the sale to the investor.
E) lose, because the investor has reasonable access to the public highway without using the right-of-way.
F) win, because the investor has a right to access all parts of her property.
G) lose, because the easement was not specifically mentioned in the deed between the farmer and the investor.
H) win, because the right-of-way was never officially terminated.
I) win, because the investor acquired an easement by implication.
J) win, because the original deed clearly states the existence of the right-of-way.

additional_args.input_str:
A farm and an orchard are adjoining tracts of land located in a county. In 2006, a farmer purchased the farm, a 10-acre tract, in fee simple absolute. The orchard, a 20-acre tract situated to the north of the farm, was owned by a rancher in fee simple absolute. A remote predecessor of the farmer had granted to a shepherd a way for egress and ingress across the farm under such terms and circumstances that an easement appurtenant to the orchard was created. This right-of-way was executed by deed and properly recorded. The shepherd, however, never made any actual use of the right-of-way. In 2010, the rancher conveyed the orchard to the farmer. The next year, the farmer conveyed the orchard by deed to an investor for a consideration of $250,000, receipt of which was acknowledged. Neither the rancher farmer deed nor the farmer  investor deed contained any reference to the easement for right-of-way. The investor has now claimed that she has a right-of-way across the farm. The farmer, on the other hand, has informed the investor that no such easement exists. Assume that both the farm and the orchard abut a public highway and that ingress and egress are afforded the investor by that highway. In an appropriate action by the investor to determine her right to use the right-of-way across the farm, she should

A) win, because the farmer had constructive notice of the easement.
B) lose, because the right-of-way was abandoned inasmuch as there never was any actual use made.
C) lose, because the easement was extinguished by merger when the farmer acquired the orchard from the rancher.
D) lose, because the easement was not in use at the time of the sale to the investor.
E) lose, because the investor has reasonable access to the public highway without using the right-of-way.
F) win, because the investor has a right to access all parts of her property.
G) lose, because the easement was not specifically mentioned in the deed between the farmer and the investor.
H) win, because the right-of-way was never officially terminated.
I) win, because the investor acquired an easement by implication.
J) win, because the original deed clearly states the existence of the right-of-way.

additional_args.task_instruction: Answer the provided question by choosing one option. Include the letter corresponding to your answer in the solution.
additional_args.input_str:
A farm and an orchard are adjoining tracts of land located in a county. In 2006, a farmer purchased the farm, a 10-acre tract, in fee simple absolute. The orchard, a 20-acre tract situated to the north of the farm, was owned by a rancher in fee simple absolute. A remote predecessor of the farmer had granted to a shepherd a way for egress and ingress across the farm under such terms and circumstances that an easement appurtenant to the orchard was created. This right-of-way was executed by deed and properly recorded. The shepherd, however, never made any actual use of the right-of-way. In 2010, the rancher conveyed the orchard to the farmer. The next year, the farmer conveyed the orchard by deed to an investor for a consideration of $250,000, receipt of which was acknowledged. Neither the rancher farmer deed nor the farmer  investor deed contained any reference to the easement for right-of-way. The investor has now claimed that she has a right-of-way across the farm. The farmer, on the other hand, has informed the investor that no such easement exists. Assume that both the farm and the orchard abut a public highway and that ingress and egress are afforded the investor by that highway. In an appropriate action by the investor to determine her right to use the right-of-way across the farm, she should

A) win, because the farmer had constructive notice of the easement.
B) lose, because the right-of-way was abandoned inasmuch as there never was any actual use made.
C) lose, because the easement was extinguished by merger when the farmer acquired the orchard from the rancher.
D) lose, because the easement was not in use at the time of the sale to the investor.
E) lose, because the investor has reasonable access to the public highway without using the right-of-way.
F) win, because the investor has a right to access all parts of her property.
G) lose, because the easement was not specifically mentioned in the deed between the farmer and the investor.
H) win, because the right-of-way was never officially terminated.
I) win, because the investor acquired an easement by implication.
J) win, because the original deed clearly states the existence of the right-of-way.

additional_args.task_instruction: Answer the provided question by choosing one option. Include the letter corresponding to your answer in the solution.
additional_args.input_str:
A farm and an orchard are adjoining tracts of land located in a county. In 2006, a farmer purchased the farm, a 10-acre tract, in fee simple absolute. The orchard, a 20-acre tract situated to the north of the farm, was owned by a rancher in fee simple absolute. A remote predecessor of the farmer had granted to a shepherd a way for egress and ingress across the farm under such terms and circumstances that an easement appurtenant to the orchard was created. This right-of-way was executed by deed and properly recorded. The shepherd, however, never made any actual use of the right-of-way. In 2010, the rancher conveyed the orchard to the farmer. The next year, the farmer conveyed the orchard by deed to an investor for a consideration of $250,000, receipt of which was acknowledged. Neither the rancher farmer deed nor the farmer  investor deed contained any reference to the easement for right-of-way. The investor has now claimed that she has a right-of-way across the farm. The farmer, on the other hand, has informed the investor that no such easement exists. Assume that both the farm and the orchard abut a public highway and that ingress and egress are afforded the investor by that highway. In an appropriate action by the investor to determine her right to use the right-of-way across the farm, she should

A) win, because the farmer had constructive notice of the easement.
B) lose, because the right-of-way was abandoned inasmuch as there never was any actual use made.
C) lose, because the easement was extinguished by merger when the farmer acquired the orchard from the rancher.
D) lose, because the easement was not in use at the time of the sale to the investor.
E) lose, because the investor has reasonable access to the public highway without using the right-of-way.
F) win, because the investor has a right to access all parts of her property.
G) lose, because the easement was not specifically mentioned in the deed between the farmer and the investor.
H) win, because the right-of-way was never officially terminated.
I) win, because the investor acquired an easement by implication.
J) win, because the original deed clearly states the existence of the right-of-way.
